ygData.subject: Re: CPPN node bloat
ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, they re probably not in there.  Phased pruning is Colin Green s idea, so it comes with SharpNEAT and its derivatives.  Derek James and Phillip Tucker

Jeff, they're probably not in there.  Phased pruning is Colin Green's ide=
a, so it comes with SharpNEAT and its derivatives.  Derek James and Phillip=
 Tucker also explored pruning in ANJI, which has that ability, although I b=
elieve it isn't phased there.

ken

> > Hi Jeff, 
> > 
> > I guess such bloat is inevitable in case of =
fitness plateau being reached. One
> > suggestion is to try pruning the net=
works with the addition of subtractive
> > mutations (remove link & remove =
node). Or better try phased searching,
> > complexification followed by sim=
plification stages. This will improve things
> > for sure. 
> > 
> > Peter
=
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >=
> Hello all-
> >> 
> >> I have been noticing in many of my HyperNEAT runs r=
ecently that the number
> >> of CPPN nodes is shooting up as a steep linear=
 function of time
> >> (generations), and is relatively unaffected by the f=
itness trajectory of the
> >> run. 
> >> 
> >> See here, for example
> >> 
=
> >> https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/delme/CPPN-Node-Bloat-1.png
> >> 
> >> Som=
etimes it gets really pathological, with almost 25 CPPN nodes being added
>=
 >> every 100 generations, such as here:
> >> 
> >> https://www.msu.edu/~jc=
lune/delme/CPPN-Node-Bloat-2.png
> >> 
> >> Oddly, and interestingly, the r=
uns in this second figure where the CPPN node
> >> count linearly increases=
 are in a changing environment and those runs where
> >> the CPPN node coun=
t flatlines (at a healthy level) are in a constant
> >> environment.
> >> 
=
> >> Are any of you seeing such bloat?
> >> 
> >> One problem is that it ma=
kes the runs slow to a crawl, because running
> >> populations with 200-nod=
e genomes is really slow. Moreover, I doubt
> >> evolution can make too muc=
h progress with that many nodes (although I have
> >> seen fitness continue=
 to increase even with such large genomes).
> >> 
> >> I have tried droppin=
g the MutateAddNodeProbability from 0.03 to 0.003 and
> >> that definitely =
changes the slope of the line, but it still linearly
> >> increases. The go=
od news is that it does not affect fitness to much.
> >> 
> >> Any thoughts=
? 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Kind regards,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >>

ion Lab, Michigan State University
